channel.title: NPR Topics: Home Page Top Stories
channel.description: Top stories in the U.S. and world news, politics, health, science, business, music, arts and culture. Nonprofit journalism with a mission. This is NPR.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

image.title: NPR Topics: Home Page Top Stories

item.title: Trump orders blockade of 'sanctioned oil tankers' into Venezuela
item.description: President Donald Trump says he is ordering a blockade of all "sanctioned oil tankers" into Venezuela, ramping up pressure on the country's authoritarian leader Nicolás Maduro.
item.content:encoded:
President Donald Trump says he is ordering a blockade of all "sanctioned oil tankers" into Venezuela, ramping up pressure on the country's authoritarian leader Nicolás Maduro.

(Image credit: Cristian Hernandez)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Nick Reiner will be charged with first degree murder in his parents' killing
item.description: The 32-year-old son of famed director Rob Reiner is being held without bail. Los Angeles authorities say the charges against him carry a maximum sentence of life in prison without the possibility of parole.
item.content:encoded:
The 32-year-old son of famed director Rob Reiner is being held without bail. Los Angeles authorities say the charges against him carry a maximum sentence of life in prison without the possibility of parole.

(Image credit: Michael Buckner)
item.dc:creator: Clare Lombardo

item.title: After outcry over prices, FIFA to sell $60 tickets for the World Cup -- with a catch
item.description: FIFA said it would sell $60 tickets to the World Cup, including for the final — but only for supporters of qualified teams. And the actual number of available tickets is limited.
item.content:encoded:
FIFA said it would sell $60 tickets to the World Cup, including for the final — but only for supporters of qualified teams. And the actual number of available tickets is limited.

(Image credit: Fabrice Coffrini)
item.dc:creator: Rafael Nam

item.title: What to know from Susie Wiles' interviews with 'Vanity Fair,' according to the writer
item.description: Throughout the year, Vanity Fair writer Chris Whipple interviewed some of the people closest to President Trump. We speak with Whipple about his talks with White House chief of staff, Susie Wiles.
item.content:encoded:
Throughout the year, Vanity Fair writer Chris Whipple interviewed some of the people closest to President Trump. We speak with Whipple about his talks with White House chief of staff, Susie Wiles.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Elena Burnett

item.title: Bondi Beach attack casts a shadow on Hanukkah celebrations in Israel
item.description: People of all ages had been looking forward to celebrating — especially this year, as a ceasefire in Gaza has held since October and all but one of the hostages taken by Hamas-led militants have been returned.
item.content:encoded:
People of all ages had been looking forward to celebrating — especially this year, as a ceasefire in Gaza has held since October and all but one of the hostages taken by Hamas-led militants have been returned.

(Image credit: Jerome Socolovsky)
item.dc:creator: Jerome Socolovsky

item.title: Psychologists are increasingly using — and worrying about — AI tools, poll finds
item.description: A survey finds that 56% of psychologists are trying out artificial intelligence tools at work, mainly for administrative tasks. A majority also are concerned about harms of AI on patients and society.
item.content:encoded: A survey finds that 56% of psychologists are trying out artificial intelligence tools at work, mainly for administrative tasks. A majority also are concerned about harms of AI on patients and society.
item.dc:creator: Rhitu Chatterjee

item.title: Her 1951 walkout helped end school segregation. Now her statue is in the U.S. Capitol
item.description: Barbara Rose Johns was 16 when she led a walkout at her high school, credited with helping end school segregation. Her statue replaces Robert E. Lee's, which was removed in 2020.
item.content:encoded:
Barbara Rose Johns was 16 when she led a walkout at her high school, credited with helping end school segregation. Her statue replaces Robert E. Lee's, which was removed in 2020.

(Image credit: Amy Davis)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Orange rivers and melting glaciers: federal report shows rapid change in the Arctic
item.description: This year's Arctic Report Card from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration finds that the northernmost part of the Earth is warming faster than the global average, leading to melting glaciers, shifting fish populations, and rivers running orange.
item.content:encoded:
This year's Arctic Report Card from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration finds that the northernmost part of the Earth is warming faster than the global average, leading to melting glaciers, shifting fish populations, and rivers running orange.

(Image credit: Josh Koch)
item.dc:creator: Barbara Moran

item.title: Search for body of last hostage held by Hamas in Gaza is delayed due to bad weather
item.description: A storm has battered the Gaza Strip, creating misery for displaced Palestinians and delaying the search for the body of the last Israeli hostage held by militants there.
item.content:encoded:
A storm has battered the Gaza Strip, creating misery for displaced Palestinians and delaying the search for the body of the last Israeli hostage held by militants there.

(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)
item.dc:creator: Hadeel Al-Shalchi

item.title: Ditching music algorithms? Here are 12 streaming alternatives to explore
item.description: If you're looking to shake things up in the new year, these streaming platforms will help you diversify your music-listening habits.
item.content:encoded: If you're looking to shake things up in the new year, these streaming platforms will help you diversify your music-listening habits.
item.dc:creator: Miguel Perez
